ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned Chinese
Continues to learn Chinese characters and speaking for important situations
Improved my Chinese speaking, listening, and writing skills, with an emphasis on in-class drills
My chinese skills
My Chinese skills improved drastically, especially in reading and writing. I learned many new grammar structures and sentence patterns along with new vocab.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought it was very well structured, though the virtual environment is not ideal

This is a fantastic course and the Chinese departament is amazing. They sincerely care about every single student and will do their best to ensure everyone succeeds. I did miss handwriting practice, but there was little that could be done during remote learning

Wang Laoshi is probably the best professor I've ever had for Chinese class. You learn so much from this course and continue to develop your Mandarin skills. As always, this will be a lot of work, but I think that's to be expected from an L4 language class.

There was honestly not much that could be improved. The nightly homeworks were rarely too much, and allowed for consistent practice. In class, Wang Laoshi was the absolute best, super engaging and positive despite the unusual circumstances and the occasional (not unwanted) interruption from her dog. The exams were very accommodating with the option to begin them at any time during the exam day and their open-book format. The only (minor) issue was the timing of individual session partner releases, since sometimes we had to camp out in the mornings to practice and prepare if the email was sent out late and we didn't know our partners.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: They adapted homework to be all online, which reduced handwriting practice. However, the engagement in lecutres (which have always been the most important component of the course) remained very high. Wang laoshi went out of her way to make lectures engaging and creative, preparing flashcards, whiteboards, and even cooking to help us engage with the language and have fun in a dynamic classroom.
I liked the tutorials because they gave us more opportunities to speak chinese

The exam formats were very accommodating, and Wang Laoshi in general was very bubbly and brought an infection good energy to class every day. She even used her kitchen to cook a meal during our unit on Chinese cuisine, which was very creative and engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely.
Yes. The Chinese program here is very dedicated and well put together.
Yes! Chinese at Yale is great
Yes yes yes yes yes yes

Absolutely! Wang Laoshi is the best, to the point where I always felt that she was nothing but supportive and accommodating and still walked away able to read Chinese texts and watch Chinese TV shows with minimal difficulty.

If you want to learn Chinese quickly, this course is perfect for you! I absolutely loved the entire department and every single professor always put student wellbeing first. Truly an incredible language department!

If you're continuing your Chinese education at Yale, absolutely! This is a good course to keep developing listening and reading comprehension skills - I feel like it was the "threshold" for me between just studying the language and being a speaker (if a really still inexperienced one) of it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual tutorial, individual sessions
Synchronous seminars, with a weekly synchronous tutorial

Weekly tutorial sessions with a TF
Weekly 10-minute individual sessions with the professor
Self-timed asynchronous exams to replace a class
